PCJ260Y1-Y-20189.courseTitle: Introduction to Peace and Conflict Studies (formerly PCS260Y1, UNI110Y1, UNI260Y1)
PCJ260Y1-Y-20189.courseDescription: A review of the full range of theories explaining the nature and causes of conflict and possibilities for its resolution; provides students with a set of theoretical tools for effective analysis of interpersonal, civil, and international conflict.
PCJ260Y1-Y-20189.prerequisite: Only for current PCJ program students in second year and higher/permission of the Program Director
PCJ260Y1-Y-20189.webTimetableInstructions: Students not in the Peace, Conflict and Justice Program must have approval from the program to take PCJ courses. Please contact the Program Administrator at pcj.program@utoronto.ca.

PCJ360H1-F-20189.courseTitle: Topics in Peace, Conflict, and Justice
PCJ360H1-F-20189.courseDescription: An in-depth exploration of selected issues in the field of Peace, Conflict, and Justice. Topics may include: negotiation theory, ethnic and inter-group identity conflict, feminist perspectives on peace, war, and justice; mathematical modeling of arms races, war, and peacemaking; decision-making theory and conflict; environmental change and conflict; global justice institutions; and traditional perspectives on statecraft.
PCJ360H1-F-20189.prerequisite: PCJ260Y1 or permission of the Program Director.
PCJ360H1-F-20189.webTimetableInstructions: Students not in the Peace, Conflict and Justice Program must have approval from the program to take PCJ courses. Please contact the Program Administrator at pcj.program@utoronto.ca.

PCJ362H1-S-20189.courseDescription: In cooperation with the Center for Community Partnerships, students will be given a service learning placement that aligns with their academic interests. These placements will happen in community organizations and other organizations based in the GTA. Class will meet once a week and students will serve up to 10 hours total per week in their placements. The course will emphasize how groups work to achieve community goals, how grassroots politics works, the power of social capital, and how these topics link to questions of conflict resolution, brokering piece, and achieving justice.
PCJ362H1-S-20189.webTimetableInstructions: Students not in the Peace, Conflict and Justice Program must have approval from the program to take PCJ courses. Please contact the Program Administrator at pcj.program@utoronto.ca.

PCJ363H1-S-20189.courseDescription: Using Blackboard, students will meet once a week online in a virtual class that will assign readings, provide writing assignments, and culminate in a group assignment that situates the training from the PCJ program within the new materials that each student is experiencing in their new university. Each student will have to reflect on how their thinking has changed, what they will do with their new perspectives when they come back to U of T, and how this affects their thinking about peace, conflict, and justice.
PCJ363H1-S-20189.webTimetableInstructions: Students not in the Peace, Conflict and Justice Program must have approval from the program to take PCJ courses. Please contact the Program Administrator at pcj.program@utoronto.ca.

PCJ460H1-F-20189.courseTitle: Contemporary Issues in Peace and Conflict (formerly PCS460H1, UNI460H1)
PCJ460H1-F-20189.courseDescription: A colloquium (fall term) on selected issues in the field of Peace and Conflict Studies. Topics to be considered include planetary, ecospheric, state, societal, and human security.
PCJ460H1-F-20189.prerequisite: PCJ360Y1, or PCJ360H1 and PCJ362H1, or permission of the Program Director; enrolment restricted to students enrolled in Peace, Conflict and Justice Specialist program
PCJ460H1-F-20189.webTimetableInstructions: Students not in the Peace, Conflict and Justice Program must have approval from the program to take PCJ courses. Please contact the Program Administrator at pcj.program@utoronto.ca.

PCJ461H1-S-20189.courseTitle: Contemporary Issues in Peace and Conflict (formerly PCS461H1, UNI460Y1)
PCJ461H1-S-20189.courseDescription: A research seminar (spring term) on selected issues in the field of Peace and Conflict Studies.  Topics to be considered include planetary, ecospheric, state, societal, and human security.
PCJ461H1-S-20189.prerequisite: PCJ360Y1 and PCJ460H1; enrolment restricted to students enrolled in the Peace, Conflict and Justice Specialist program
PCJ461H1-S-20189.webTimetableInstructions: Please note that this course is only open to students enrolled in the PCJ Specialist Programs during the Priority Enrolment period on ACORN, which is until August 6. After this date, students not in the Peace, Conflict and Justice Programs must have approval from PCJ to add the course. Please contact the Program Administrator at pcj.program@utoronto.ca.

PCJ499H1-F-20189.courseTitle: Peace and Conflict Studies Independent Study Course (formerly PCS499H1)
PCJ499H1-F-20189.courseDescription: Independent study in the area of Peace and Conflict Studies. It is designed to provide students with the opportunity to explore topics not covered in the curriculum, or to develop a more detailed focus on topics covered. Approval of the Program Director is required. The student must obtain the written agreement of the instructor who will supervise the independent study. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.
PCJ499H1-F-20189.recommendedPreparation: For students enrolled in the Peace, Conflict and Justice Major or Specialist program.
PCJ499H1-F-20189.webTimetableInstructions: Students not in the Peace, Conflict and Justice Program must have approval from the program to take PCJ courses. Please contact the Program Administrator at pcj.program@utoronto.ca.
